utterances.utterance: He was a famous guy, by the way. It's not as if no one knew who he was. Like he works for the Harlem Globetrotters. He worked for the WNBA team, like this guy is well known.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: He's also black.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Exactly. That's the point. Everyone knows it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But the reason why he did that is because he thought he could get away -- not the D.J. but the person making the accusation feels that they have everybody on their side. The woke -- like no one's going to question.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: But in today's world, anybody going to do that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: I mean, it's just unthinkable, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: But that -- but that's -- but that's what the problem here is that the serious side of -- and it is hilarious but the serious side of it is the fact that they're actually making race relations in this country worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: You know, you know normal people have sort of moved on from all of this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: And you have this group of people who have become the race police also known as bigots.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. They're like the -- what do you mean, they're like the -- those Japanese pilots stuck on the island.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't know the war is over.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The woke -- they don't understand.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: That's putting it charitably too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It is. It is. I -- yes. That is true. All right. It's not so bad being stuck on an island, you know.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Depends --

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: As long as you have your unicorns.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. Enough of the unicorns, Charlie. I'll kill you. I swear. Up next. Twitter's dysfunction on full display as Elon continues to laugh and play. I'm just kidding.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm way hotter now than, when I was 21. I'll have you know. They're still freaking out about Elon's growing clout. Elon Musk has been slammed in the media for as offer to by Twitter and cutting his own hair. Critics say, a billionaire in charge of a media company is bad for free speech democracy. But here's the thing, many of Elon's critics belong to media companies currently owned by billionaires. Facebook and Instagram are owned by Mark Zuckerberg billionaire, Jeff Bezos bought the Washington Post in 2016, he's a space alien. The Atlantic, a magazine and an ocean, is majority, is majority-owned by Lauren, Steve Jobs's widow. And Time Magazine is owned by billionaire, Marc Benioff, and Bloomberg obviously is owned by Howard Hughes. Los Angeles Times owned by billionaire Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong -- I did not know that. Elon points out that the Twitter board collectively owns almost zero shares, yet they get paid a salary for being on the board.

utterances.speaker: No wonder they're scared of him. He could take their influence and their paychecks away. So, he's got the media and the billionaire benefactors in a tizzy. That has to be a good thing. You know, it's like my rich Uncle Marty used to say
utterances.utterance: give a man a fish and you feed him for a day, but teach a man to fish, and while he's fishing, you go to his house bang his wife. Yes, he was, he was such a (BLEEP), Charlie, but he was right on that one.

utterances.speaker: CHARLIE HURT, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Wow!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I taught a lot of men to fish. I don't even --

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Lock up your wife.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think Bill Maher is going to take back what he said about this show. You know, Charlie, I have, I've not had you on the show since this homeless thing. This is a -- you got to be enjoying every minute of this right? Do you think he's going to pull it off, he's going to pull it off?

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: I hope he does. I pray he does. I think it would be the greatest thing for a free press in this country, in -- perhaps in our lifetimes. And it's kind of interesting, because, of course, wealthy people have always owned all the printing presses. Of course, that's kind of the way it works. The great revolution of the Internet was that it Democratized everything.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: And there are good things about that and there are bad things about that. But you can't, you can't argue with the fact that it's generally going in a very positive direction if you want more voices, and you believe in free press.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: And watching these people, especially in the free press department, like in newspapers and, and magazines freaking out over the concept that you've got this guy who says, you know what I want to I want to protect and preserve this press for everybody and give everybody a voice watching them freak out. They have completely revealed --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly because they want them, they want the microphone for them. But they don't want the microphone for other people. Kat, here's an interesting question. Oh, you're going to love this. If you had the -- did I already asked you this?

utterances.speaker: KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know because you haven't said it this time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It just felt like, would you -- I feel like I asked you this last week. What would you purchase? Like he's purchasing something to fix it? If you had unlimited money? What would you purchase --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Just -- no, I just didn't get a PJ for myself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A P.J.?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Private jet. That's all I really want.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, but -- well, I mean --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: What would I pick? What would I buy?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is this -- like, I would --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I'm not in the business of fixing anything.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would buy Rolling Stone magazine because I grew up on it, and it's terrible now and I would want to fix it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Can I buy the city of Detroit?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go. There you go. That's probably cheaper than Twitter.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I would love to buy it. I would love to buy Detroit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: So, yes, I would buy Detroit, but don't worry I'll make it fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Thoughts on Elon, any new thoughts on Elon?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: This is just crazy. It's like people just throw billionaire around like, oh, and it's like, yes, billionaires own stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: They buy stuff with their billions.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly, what do you expect them to do, like be on a budget? Oh, I can only spend $38.00. No, you're Elon Musk. You can buy -- if you want to by Twitter, buy five Twitters and set them on fire. I don't know. I don't even know if that's possible, Doctor, am I worrying you?

utterances.speaker: DR. DREW PINSKY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: This whole thing worries me. A couple of things, a couple things. First of all, what happen to the stockholders? Why don't they get to vote on this? I don't understand why that's not the first order of business of a board representing the stockholders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's not a lot of stock on the board, but there's a lot of stock among the stock.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Stockholders. And the other thing I've noticed is that the term free press -- there's a lot of monkeying with language, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. DOC? And the word, the term Free Press is starting to shift. You don't even know what they're talking about anymore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Because clearly Elon wants freer, freer expression -- now, that's not free press. Free press is something processed and controlled to protect democracy. That's what it is. Which I'm not sure what that is. You know, Charlie, I don't know what that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's down there talking about content moderation, which everybody does in life. We content -- believe it or not, we moderate the content of this show. But I mean, but they're using it in a different way. They're using it as a, as, as what do you call it a dog whistle for censorship? You see what I did there, Emily? I bet you should do what would you take a hostile takeover if you could do would you do like that? Would you do the L.A. Raiders?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The Oakland Raiders?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Oakland Raiders, is that where they are --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: They don't need fixing, they're just fine.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're in Las Vegas, lady. I tricked you.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I know, but I call them Oakland Raiders for life, forever.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Anyway, here's what I thought totally summed up this whole situation, which is one of the writers for The Atlantic, right? He's talking about Elon Musk, and how audacious and crazy this is. He called him a billionaire (BLEEP). And he said, he basically is a purveyor of infantile jackass-ery, whose unfathomable wealth makes it possible and even likely that we'll carry out even the most ridiculous plan. That's exactly what having wealth plus vision is. And I feel like what sets Elon Musk apart is that he has that vision. How dare he privatize space, in conjunction with NASA, which was sort of a dying agency, like he provided a spark that benefited literally in the future hundreds of millions of people. And yet, we're supposed to look down on him for that, because he has a vision. It's exactly the same thing, too, that Silicon Valley is already doing, which is pooling their wealth or concentrating their wealth and buying the same (BLEEP).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It's just that one person does it with a commitment and a vision to make something that has turned toxic, actually wonderful again, right? He's trying to create or restore a virtual town square, and we're supposed to hate him for it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And the -- I think the solute, I mean, what the benefit to that is that it is the drug drip for the journalists. And it's like, it's like, there are more people on Facebook, but all the journalists flow every morning, and I include myself in this even though I'm not a journalist anymore, but they'd suck off that. They would --

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: They're on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're on Twitter, but they got to get all the rage. And if, and if he turns that off, then it's gone, then journalists have to chase stories instead of retweets.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: But this is what we have seen over the course of our career in this business, is that the beauty of Twitter is that it is an extraordinary vehicle for, for sharing information. The press, the reporters saw it as an amazing vehicle to talk about themselves.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And manipulate narratives as well. It's about me, it's about me and how important I am and then also the stories that I'm working on. And that's right, it's supposed, it's supposed to be sharing information, not manipulating it. I would -- if I could, if I were Elon Musk, I would definitely buy Grit. Do you remember Grit?

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: The movie?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That rural tabloid?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Remember, they used to advertise in the back of comic books? Hey, buy Grit -- below guy with a newspaper bag?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Nope.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't believe I out aged all of you. How old are you, Dr. Drew? You and I are the same age?

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: I think I'm a little older.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, I really?

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes. But I've never heard Grit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You never heard Grit?

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You people all suck.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Maybe when I was in medical school. There was a period where I was in training and I just don't know what happened.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I've been there I was in, I was in a medical college for a while. Coming up on Easter, Trump wish the lefties Well, instead of telling him to go to hell.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, what's in East -- what's in Trump's Easter basket insults to make the Dems blow a gasket. Trump keeps his enemies near while spreading Easter cheer. He released this statement yesterday. This is so good. "Happy Easter to all including the radical left maniacs who were doing everything possible to destroy our country. May they not succeed, but let them nevertheless, be happy, healthy, wealthy and well." So funny. Trump's Save America PAC also wished a "Happy Easter to failed gubernatorial candidate and racist Attorney General Letitia James." "May she remain healthy despite the fact that she will continue to drive business out of New York while at the same time keeping crime, death, and destruction in New York." That's Easter. That is way better than anything from Hallmark. And only Trump can make you feel dirty while taking the high road. Hopefully, these messages will become a new Eastern tradition like wearing bonnets and food poisoning. And why not appears more and more things Trump was alarmed about came true like Germany's gas pipeline deal with Russia. Remember this from 2018? DONALD TRUMP, 45TH PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's very sad when Germany makes a massive oil and gas deal with Russia, where you're supposed to be guarding against Russia and Germany goes out and pays billions and billions of dollars a year to Russia.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We are stronger together.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: But how can you be together when a country is getting its energy from the person you want protection against or from the group that you want protection?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Miss that. Of course, people mocked him for being concerned about it four years ago.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.utterance: The world gone crazy this morning. Trump's performance was beyond belief.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I've never seen a president say anything as strange or counterproductive as President Trump's harangue against NATO and Germany.

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: It sounds like the president is engaging in what about ism instead of responding to criticism that he's too cozy, cozy with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This sort of had that same feeling the president facing a lot of criticism that he's a puppet to Vladimir Putin, and saying, I'm not it's Germany that is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: That footage that you showed at the beginning of the show, by the way he put in a time capsule.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, should you. I don't even know who you are. He was right, they're all wrong. Germany's struggling to survive without Russian oil. How'd that happen? This is all as the Biden administration announces it will sell leases to drill on federal lands. Something he had it originally campaigned against. But we can't expect Joe to remember that when he forgets who the Easter Bunny is. That music makes it. Kat, what -- was that the best Easter message you've ever heard, Donald Trump? He went -- he wished them the best.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I will say he definitely wrote it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's one of the greatest writers --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: He wrote it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- in American history.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: People were, you know, comparing like the Biden's Easter matches versus Trump's. It's like Biden has a team. Everybody. When you get to that level, you have a team of writers. But Trump is very much like the statement guy is me. I'm that guy. I'm going to write it. So, yes, I mean, it sounds like what he says on like, every holiday though.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, he does. You know, I can't help, Doctor Drew, but feel that his is a message of hope.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Whenever he sends a message, yes, there is a certain group of people this country that really go cry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: And I would argue that, that, that degree of spin that they get into carried all the way into COVID. I don't understand what happened to people, why it's so upsetting to them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They -- I think it's what you're saying. They're just not used to hearing from a person. They're used to hearing from a team.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: My family group chat on Easter was worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How did it go?

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Who was it? Who said it?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's try to keep the show on point, the very organized, sophisticated endeavor. And I am a model of something. Lost my train of thought there, Emily, you aren't sure how you feel about this, do you?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Well, I felt like his Easter message was sort of half the Princess Bride, you know the bishop in it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: And half the grace in Talladega Nights where he's like, sweet, you know what I mean? Like, it's, it's like half serious and then half the caveat, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Right. And then also for Kerry's whole, like I've never seen anything so counterproductive, like Joe Biden hold my beer. Because every day of his presidency, we have been subjected to absolute mental rot and invertebrate incompetence. Trump's an absolute genius, comparatively -- I'm not wrong. I'm not wrong --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wrong at all. Not at all. And it's funny, it's like, there's a theory going around from one of our friends. It's the rearview mirror theory that the further that Trump gets behind, and we'll get further in the rearview mirror, all of his stuff is looking better and better and better. So, he's like, you know, it's, it's funny, and then you try to figure OK, yes, he pissed off a lot of people, but all the deeds he ends up directionally true on.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. We've never seen one of those things the way we have with him in politics.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: I mean, but just because, you know, the change was so dramatic. But, but this is a perfect example, going back to the Twitter thing. You know, this is what's, this is the press on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: How it is that you have a guy like Donald Trump, who's in the White House, doing all -- if you love the news, you can't not love Donald Trump as president. It is -- he provides a lot of news. And obviously, you can disagree with his position on things, and he was right about a lot of things, if not just about everything.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: But you can have those disagreements, but from an entertainment value, from a news value, I don't understand how these people don't appreciate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I always call Trump a news potato. Because you know, you can make a million things out of a potato? You can have casserole, you can have a baked potato, twice baked potato, french fries, curly fries, hashbrowns, tater tots. That's Trump. You can make like 70 different meals out of him. It's like, like, you would -- feel a show if he was around.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: Yes, and we did. If Trump had been alive during Shakespeare's time, Shakespeare would have like, rewritten like all of his histories, all of his comedies, all of his tragedies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: To insert this amazing character, Trump, in into all of them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's an interesting theory, but I don't think we'll be able to prove it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes, I haven't talked through.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, we have to -- how's your time machine working?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Not yet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. Will it be ready yesterday?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I get it.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: A little time travel humor.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: That's really good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, thank you. I knew you were going to say that. Up next, an open invitation for an alien invasion. What is wrong with me today?

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: "A STORY IN FIVE WORDS."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want to see it? We're short on time. So, here's a story in five words: Earth's location will invite invasion. Doctor Drew, NASA plans to beam Earth's location into outer space. Some people think that could trigger an alien invasion. Why are we so thirsty?

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: We're thirsty, we are grandiose, we assume that aliens are as aggressive as we are. Who knows? They're probably nothing like us, whatsoever. But one interesting thing, that, that image that you saw on the screen with next to me, that is the product of something called hypnagogic hallucination that has been quite well shown now that when I have these hallucinations in a sleep state, that's what they --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have them too. I used to get those all the time when I was younger, they'd wake up and be on my chest breathing.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: To be right on my chest. You know, they said that I was the inspiration for gargoyles.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Isn't that crazy.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: So, this is something that humans concocted in their head, and we've decided that today.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's hypnagogic --

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: You have it too?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I didn't know that. No, I just didn't know that. You're blowing my mind. Aliens don't actually look like that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Aliens do not look -- are you out of your mind, Emily? What do you think -- you know what, we -- know, would it be great -- you know, we keep thinking they're our size, what if aliens was super tiny, they could be on your sight?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Well, I firmly believe that they're part of our shared consciousness and that they're definitely purposely not landing because we totally suck. However, what I will say, is that we already beamed out our location in 1974 from Puerto Rico. So, this whole thing is crap. It's just fear mongering because if they were going to invade, they would have done it already, obviously.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Or they don't want to go to Puerto Rico?

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: What day?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, yes, I mean, if I was going to invade, I was going to go hang out, I wouldn't.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: If I was going to look at this place, I'll be like, yes, I'm going to go to the next planet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, but you know what, you know, we eat cattle. I want to eat an alien because it's like, you know, once we have space aliens, I don't -- why are we eating Earthlings? Let's just eat them. Like if they come in peace, turn them into pizza. That's what I say, Charlie.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That's so messed up.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: I used to think that the best bumper sticker for Trump 2016 would be: Trump for president, and you can't screw it up. I'm ready now just to put the aliens in charge.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: They do come back? Put them in charge. Put them in the White House.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what, they -- you know what, they might be in charge. We don't know really where COVID came from, do we? COVID could actually be a space alien, right?

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: Maybe that explains Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it explains a lot of things like why I can't blink? You know, Kat, what do you think about that? COVID could have been a space alien that came in in his in our bloodstream. It comes in our blood, right?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I think there's your next book.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Really?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
